Sun of Faith - English: King Shuddhodana consulted with his ministers.
Manual - English: The Buddha enters the city in a carriage. He prophesies to many brahmins who are leaving the city.
Scene working notes: This scene, wherein the Buddha enters the city in a carriage and offers a prophecy to some bramins, is mentioned only in the bris yig. The mural depicts this in the uninscribed scene drawn out as Scene 1.

Sun of Faith - English: They said, "We shall bring all the beautiful young women of the land before young Siddartha, and he will choose whomever delights him most. To do that, since the Youth delights in generosity, we shall arrange for him to give jewelry to the women. And then we shall know the one he likes the best."
And so on a very auspicious astrologicaly determined date, they set up a lion throne in a broad square and the the Bodhisattva sat upon it.
Manual - English: In a broad courtyard, the Buddha gives a gift item to each of the many Shakya girls. The Buddha gives a finger ring to Yashodhara (grags 'dzin ma).

Sun of Faith - English: They piled up a heap of various kinds of jewelry and prepared. The head's of all the major families gathered around.
All the women from noble families, adorned with finery in accordance with their status, filed past.  lined up in accordance with their station.
To each the Bodhisattva presented a piece of jewelry.
Inscription - English: The Youth gives jewelry to ordinary maidens,[Inscription illegible]

Sun of Faith - English: However Yashodhara, daughter of the Shakya Dandapani, would not approach him.
The father said, “The Youth is giving jewelry so go!”
"Do we not have enough jewels?" she asked.
“That's not it,” said the father. “The youth is choosing a wife.”
“Whether he selects me or not, he alone will be my husband.” she said.
“In that case," the father said, "you should certainly go."
So Yashodhara, who was radiant like a goddess among women, approached after everyone else.
But by then the Bodhisattva had given away all the jewelry.
He showed her the only thing he had left, the signet ring on his finger. She ascended the steps to the throne and took it off the Bodhisattva's finger herself.
Then the ministers and the family heads of the land said, 'This one will suit the Youth,' and they told the king.
So the Bodhisattva took as his wife the divine Yashodhara, together with her entourage of twenty-thousand.
Manual - English: In a mansion, there is a wedding banquet for taking Yashodhara as his bride.
